{{see also|2012 in sports|Portal:Sports}} {{Month year in topic|month=July|year=2012|topic=sports}} {{TOC right|limit=3}} ==Days of the month==
===28 July 2012 (Saturday)=== ====[[Rugby union]]==== *[[2012 Super Rugby season#Semi-Finals|Super Rugby Semifinals]] in [[Newlands Stadium|Cape Town, Western Cape]], [[South Africa]]: [[Stormers]] {{flagicon|RSA}} 19–26 {{flagicon|RSA}} '''[[Sharks (rugby union)|Sharks]]'''
===27 July 2012 (Friday)=== ====[[Rugby union]]==== *[[2012 Super Rugby season#Semi-Finals|Super Rugby Semifinals]] in [[Waikato Stadium|Hamilton, Waikato]], [[New Zealand]]: '''[[Chiefs (rugby union)|Chiefs]]''' {{flagicon|NZL}} 20–17 {{flagicon|NZL}} [[Crusaders (rugby union)|Crusaders]]
===23 July 2012 (Monday)=== ====[[Baseball]]==== *[[Nippon Professional Baseball All-Star Series]]: **Game 3 in [[Iwate Prefectural Baseball Stadium|Morioka, Iwate]]: [[Pacific League]] 6, [[Central League]] 2. '''Central League win series 2–1'''. ***[[Hokkaido Nippon-Ham Fighters]] outfielder [[DaiKan Yoh]] is named game MVP with three hits and four RBIs, including a game-winning three-run home run in the 3rd inning.
===22 July 2012 (Sunday)=== ====[[Equestrianism]]==== *Show jumping: [[2012 Royal International Horse Show|Royal International Horse Show]] in [[All England Jumping Course at Hickstead|Hickstead]], [[United Kingdom]] (CSIO 5*): ** [[2012 Royal International Horse Show#The Longines King Georges V Gold Cup|King Georges V Gold Cup]]: {{gold1}} Hendrik-Jan Schuttert {{cc3|NED}} on ''Cerona'' {{silver2}} [[Ludger Beerbaum]] {{cc3|GER}} on ''Chiara'' {{bronze3}} Marie Hecart {{cc3|FRA}} on ''Myself de Breve'' ====[[Sumo]]==== *[[2012 in sumo#July|Nagoya basho (July grand tournament)]] in [[Aichi Prefectural Gymnasium|Nagoya, Aichi]], [[Japan]]: **[[Harumafuji Kōhei]] defeats [[Hakuhō Shō]] to finish the tournament with a perfect 15–0 record, and wins his 3rd [[List of sumo tournament top division winners|makuuchi (top division) championship]].
===21 July 2012 (Saturday)=== ====[[Baseball]]==== *[[Nippon Professional Baseball All-Star Series]]: **Game 2 in [[Botchan Stadium|Matsuyama, Ehime]]: [[Central League]] 4, [[Pacific League]] 0. ''Central League lead series 2–0''. ***[[Hiroshima Toyo Carp]] pitcher [[Kenta Maeda]] wins game MVP after pitching three scoreless innings with only one hit. ====[[Equestrianism]]==== *[[Show jumping]]: [[2012 Global Champions Tour|Global Champions Tour]]: **[[2012 Global Champions Tour#8th Competition: Chantilly|8th competition]] in [[Chantilly Racecourse|Chantilly]] (CSI 5*): {{gold1}} Hans-Dieter Dreher {{cc3|GER}} on ''Magnus Romeo'' {{silver2}} [[Beezie Madden]] {{cc3|USA}} on ''Simon'' {{bronze3}} Karim El Zoghby {{cc3|EGY}} on ''Splendor'' ====[[Mixed martial arts]]==== *[[2012 in UFC#UFC 149: Faber vs. Barao|UFC 149]] in [[Scotiabank Saddledome|Calgary, Alberta]], [[Canada]] (USA unless stated): **Welterweight bout: '''[[Matt Riddle (fighter)|Matt Riddle]]''' def. [[Chris Clements (fighter)|Chris Clements]] {{cc3|CAN}} via submission (arm-triangle choke) **Welterweight bout: '''[[James Head (fighter)|James Head]]''' def. [[Brian Ebersole]] via split decision (29–28, 28–29, 29–28) **Heavyweight bout: '''[[Cheick Kongo]]''' {{cc3|FRA}} def. [[Shawn Jordan]] via unanimous decision (30–28, 30–27, 30–27) **Middleweight bout: '''[[Tim Boetsch]]''' def. [[Hector Lombard]] {{cc3|CUB}} via split decision (29–28, 28–29, 29–28) **[[List of UFC champions#Bantamweight Championship|Interim Bantamweight Championship]] bout: '''[[Renan Barão]]''' {{cc3|BRA}} def. [[Urijah Faber]] via unanimous decision (49–46, 50–45, 49–46) ====[[Rugby union]]==== *[[2012 Super Rugby season#Qualifiers|Super Rugby Qualifying finals]]: **In [[Rugby League Park|Christchurch, Canterbury]], [[New Zealand]]: '''[[Crusaders (rugby union)|Crusaders]]''' {{flagicon|NZL}} 28–13 {{flagicon|RSA}} [[Bulls (rugby union)|Bulls]] **In [[Lang Park|Brisbane, Queensland]], [[Australia]]: [[Queensland Reds|Reds]] {{flagicon|AUS}} 17–30 {{flagicon|RSA}} '''[[Sharks (rugby union)|Sharks]]'''
===20 July 2012 (Friday)=== ====[[Baseball]]==== *[[Nippon Professional Baseball All-Star Series]]: **Game 1 in [[Osaka Dome|Osaka]]: [[Central League]] 4, [[Pacific League]] 1. ''Central League lead series 1–0''. ***[[Yokohama DeNA BayStars]] third baseman [[Norihiro Nakamura]] is named game MVP after hitting a game-winning two-run home run in the 2nd inning. ====[[Equestrianism]]==== *[[Show jumping]]: [[2012 FEI Nations Cup|FEI Nations Cup]]: **7th competition: [[2012 Royal International Horse Show#FEI Nations Cup of the United Kingdom|Nations Cup of the United Kingdom]] in [[All England Jumping Course at Hickstead|Hickstead]] (CSIO 5*): {{gold1}} {{IRL}} ([[Shane Breen]], Richie Moloney, Darragh Kerins, Clement McMahon) {{silver2}} {{FRA}} (Eugénie Angot, Kevin Staut, Aymeric de Ponnat, Pénélope Leprevost) {{bronze3}} {{DEU}} (Philipp Weishaupt, Holger Wulschner, [[Ludger Beerbaum]], [[Marco Kutscher]])
===15 July 2012 (Sunday)=== ====[[Equestrianism]]==== *[[2012 Falsterbo Horse Show|Falsterbo Horse Show]] in [[Skanör med Falsterbo]], [[Sweden]]: **Dressage (CDI 5*): [[2012 Falsterbo Horse Show#Grand Prix Freestyle (A-Final)|Grand Prix Freestyle]]: {{gold1}} Patrik Kittel {{cc3|SWE}} on ''Scandic'' {{silver2}} [[Isabell Werth]] {{cc3|GER}} on ''El Santo NRW'' {{bronze3}} Tinne Vilhelmson-Silfven {{cc3|SWE}} on ''Favourit'' **Show jumping (CSIO 5*): [[2012 Falsterbo Horse Show#Longines Falsterbo Grand Prix|Grand Prix]]: {{gold1}} Nicola Philippaerts {{cc3|BEL}} on ''Carlos'' {{silver2}} Brianne Goutal {{cc3|USA}} on ''Nice de Prissey'' {{bronze3}} Peder Fredricson {{cc3|SWE}} on ''Cash In''

[[Robbie Lawler]] via unanimous decision (30–27, 30–27, 30–27) **Middleweight bout: '''[[Roger Gracie]]''' {{cc3|BRA}} def. [[Keith Jardine]] via unanimous decision (29–27, 30–27, 30–26) **[[List of Strikeforce champions#Welterweight Championship|Welterweight Championship]] bout: '''[[Nate Marquardt]]''' def. [[Tim Kennedy (fighter)|Tim Kennedy]] via unanimous decision (49–46, 49–46, 49–46)

[[Anthony Njokuani]] {{cc3|NGA}} via unanimous decision (30–27, 30–27, 29–28) **Bantamweight bout: '''[[T.J. Dillashaw]]''' {{cc3|USA}} def. [[Vaughan Lee (fighter)|Vaughan Lee]] {{cc3|ENG}} via submission (rear-naked crank) **Middleweight bout: '''[[Francis Carmont]]''' {{cc3|FRA}} def. [[Karlos Vemola]] {{cc3|CZE}} via submission (rear-naked choke) **Welterweight bout: '''[[Aaron Simpson (fighter)|Aaron Simpson]]''' {{cc3|USA}} def. [[Kenny Robertson]] {{cc3|USA}} via unanimous decision (30–27, 29–28, 29–28) **Light Heavyweight bout: '''[[James Te-Huna]]''' {{cc3|NZL}} def. [[Joey Beltran]] {{cc3|USA}} via unanimous decision (30–26, 30–27, 30–27) **Middleweight bout: '''[[Chris Weidman]]''' {{cc3|USA}} def. [[Mark Muñoz]] {{cc3|USA}} via KO (elbow and punches)

[[San Francisco Giants]] outfielder [[Melky Cabrera]] is named as [[Major League Baseball All-Star Game Most Valuable Player Award|Most Valuable Player]], with two hits including a two-run homer in {{Infobox basketball club | color1 = #FFFFFF | color2 = #EC1C24 | color3 = #D1AA67 | name = Crvena zvezda Youth | nickname = ''Crveno-beli'' (The Red-Whites)
''Zvezda'' (The Star) | logo = | logo_size = 150px | leagues = | founded = | history = | arena = | capacity = | location = [[Belgrade]], [[Serbia]] | colors = Red, white
{{color box|#EC1C24}} {{color box|#FFFFFF}} | sponsor = [[Mobile Telephony of Serbia]] | president = [[Nebojša Čović]] | manager = | coach = Bojan Đerić (U19)
[[Slobodan Klipa]] (U16) | captain = | ret_nums = | championships = '''1''' [[Euroleague Basketball Next Generation Tournament|EuroLeague NGT]] | h_body = F20D2F | h_pattern_b = _3stripesonwhite | h_shorts = F20D2F | h_pattern_s = _blanksidesandhems | a_body = F20D2F | a_pattern_b = _3whitestripes | a_shorts = F20D2F | a_pattern_s = _whitesidesandhems | website = {{URL|http://www.kkcrvenazvezda.rs/}} | current = }} '''Juniori KK Crvena zvezda''' are the [[youth team|under-18 and under-19 team]] of [[Serbia|Serbian]] men's professional [[basketball]] [[Sports club|club]] [[KK Crvena zvezda|Crvena zvezda]]. They play in the RODA Junior Basketball League of Serbia{{cite web|title=RODA Juniorska liga Srbije|url=http://www.takmicenje.kss.rs/roda-juniorska-liga-srbije/|website=takmicenje.kss.rs|accessdate=20 January 2018}} and the [[Junior Adriatic League]].{{cite web|title=Junior ABA League|url=http://www.aba-liga.com/standings_junior.php|website=aba-liga.com|accessdate=20 January 2018}} They have won [[Euroleague Basketball Next Generation Tournament]]. Some of the most notable home-grown players of Crvena zvezda are [[Zoran Slavnić]], a member of the [[FIBA's 50 Greatest Players (1991)|50 greatest players in the history]] of [[FIBA]] international basketball, as selected in 1991, then [[Igor Rakočević]] – the three-time [[Alphonso Ford EuroLeague Top Scorer Trophy|EuroLeague Top Scorer]], [[Peja Stojaković]] – the [[List of NBA All-Stars|NBA All-Star]] player and [[FIBA EuroBasket MVP]], as well as [[Vladimir Cvetković]] and [[Dragan Kapičić]]. Further notable home-grown players include [[Goran Rakočević]], [[Žarko Koprivica]], [[Slobodan Nikolić]], [[Predrag Bogosavljev]], [[Boban Janković]], [[Mirko Milićević]], [[Branislav Prelević]], [[Aleksandar Trifunović (basketball)|Aleksandar Trifunović]], [[Nebojša Ilić (basketball)|Nebojša Ilić]], [[Saša Obradović]], [[Rastko Cvetković]], [[Nikola Jestratijević]], [[Miloš Vujanić]], [[Vladimir Radmanović]], [[Milko Bjelica]], [[Luka Bogdanović]], [[Tadija Dragićević]], [[Nemanja Nedović]] and [[Marko Gudurić]]. [[Aleksandar Đorđević]] (one of [[50 Greatest EuroLeague Contributors (2008)|50 Greatest EuroLeague Contributors]]) and [[Marko Jarić]] were also members of the Crvena zvezda's youth selections but they haven't played a single game for the first team. == History == Crvena zvezda captured its first [[Euroleague Basketball Next Generation Tournament|Euroleague Basketball Nike International Junior Tournament]] title by beating [[Real Madrid Baloncesto B|Real Madrid]] 55-42 in the final Sunday at Mediolanim Forum in [[Milan]].{{cite web|title=IJT CRVENA ZVEZDA TELEKOM BELGRADE 55 IJT REAL MADRID 42|url=http://www.adidasngt.com/u18/game-center/games/showgame?gamecode=79&seasoncode=JT13#!boxscore|website=adidasngt.com|accessdate=2 April 2018}} The team featured [[Stefan Kenić]], Jovan Anđelković, [[Danilo Ostojić]], [[Vojislav Stojanović]], [[Nikola Rakićević]], Bratislav Jerković, [[Aleksa Radanov]], [[David Miladinović]], [[Marko Radovanović]], [[Boriša Simanić]], [[Aleksandar Aranitović]], [[Stefan Lazarević (basketball)|Stefan Lazarević]]. In the [[2014–15 Euroleague Basketball Next Generation Tournament|2014–15 Euroleague NGT season]] Finals, Crvena zvezda got defeated Real Madrid with 70–73. The team was coached by [[Slobodan Klipa]] and featured Ivan Ćorović, [[Nemanja Kapetanović]], Aleksandar Aranitović, Vojislav Stojanović, Aleksa Radanov, Stefan Kenić, Jovan Drljača, David Miladinović, Nikola Popović, Boriša Simanić, Nikola Rakićević, and [[Matija Radović]].{{cite web|title=U18 Real Madrid 73 U18 Crvena Zvezda Telekom Belgrade 70|url=http://www.adidasngt.com/u18/game-center/games/showgame?gamecode=78&seasoncode=JT14|website=adidasngt.com|accessdate=20 January 2018}} In the [[2015–16 Euroleague Basketball Next Generation Tournament|2015–16 Euroleague NGT season]] Finals, Crvena zvezda got defeated [[FC Barcelona Bàsquet B|FC Barcelona Lassa]] with 82–90.{{cite web|title=Barcelona wins Adidas Next Generation title, beats Crvena Zvezda|url=https://www.talkbasket.net/20391-barcelona-wins-adidas-next-generation-title-beats-crvena-zvezda|website=talkbasket.net|accessdate=20 January 2018}}{{cite web|title=Crvena zvezda are the vice-champions of Europe|url=http://www.aba-liga.com/news.php?id=36575|website=aba-liga.com|accessdate=20 January 2018}} The team was coached by [[Branko Maksimović (basketball)|Branko Maksimović]] and featured Petar Rebić, [[Aleksa Uskoković]], Ivan Ćorović, Milan Radaković, Uroš Ilić, [[Stefan Momirov]], Srećko Gašić, Boriša Simanić, Aleksa Radanov, Matija Radović, [[Stefan Đorđević (basketball)|Stefan Đorđević]] and Vladimir Kovačević.{{cite web|title=U18 FC BARCELONA LASSA 90 U18 CRVENA ZVEZDA TELEKOM BELGRADE 82|url=http://www.adidasngt.com/u18/game-center/games/showgame?gamecode=13&seasoncode=JTF415#!boxscore|website=adidasngt.com|accessdate=20 January 2018}} Boriša Simanić won the MVP Finals Award. {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} {{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Saint Petersburg Stadium | image = Spb 06-2017 img40 Krestovsky Stadium (cropped).jpg |image_size = 320px | caption =

'''[[UEFA Elite stadium|UEFA]]''' {{rating|4|4}}

| location = Futbol'naya Alleya 1, [[Krestovsky Island]], [[Saint Petersburg]], Russia | coordinates = {{coord|59|58|22.63|N|30|13|13.92|E|type:landmark|display=it}} | publictransit = {{STPETERSBURGMETRO-line3}} [[Novokrestovskaya (Saint Petersburg Metro)|Novokrestovskaya Station]]
{{STPETERSBURGMETRO-line5}} [[Krestovsky Ostrov (Saint Petersburg Metro)|Krestovsky Ostrov Station]] | broke_ground = 2007 | opened = 2017 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = Fc Zenit Saint Petersburg | operator = [[FC Zenit Saint Petersburg]] | surface = Grass | construction_cost = [[Russian ruble|₽]] 48 billion
[[Euro|€]] 653 million
[[United States dollar|$]]1.1 billion{{cite web|url=http://ksp.org.ru/article/633200018/831/Informaciya-o-rezultatah-kontrolnogo-meropriyatiya-Monitoring-ispolzovaniya-byudzhetnyh-sredstv-napravlennyh-na-proektirovanie-i-stroitelstvo-futbolnogo-stadiona-v-zapadnoy-chasti-Krestovskogo-ostrova-s-razborkoy-suschestvuyuschih-konstrukciy-stadion|title=ПРОВЕРКИ ОРГАНОВ ГОСУДАРСТВЕННОЙ ВЛАСТИ|publisher=}} | architect = [[Kisho Kurokawa]] | former_names = | tenants = [[FC Zenit Saint Petersburg|FC Zenit St. Petersburg]] (2017–present)
[[Russia national football team]] (selected matches) | seating_capacity = 67,800 ([[Russian Premier League]]){{cite web |url=https://eng.premierliga.ru/stadiums/stadiums_1758.html |title=Arena St Petersburg}}
64,468 (2018 FIFA World Cup){{cite web |url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/destination/stadiums/stadium=5031303/index.html |title=Saint Petersburg Stadium |website=FIFA |access-date=15 June 2018}} | dimensions = 105 x 68 m | website = [http://arena.fc-zenit.ru/ Official website] }} '''Krestovsky Stadium'''{{cite web|url=http://piterarena.com/news/2016/stadion-poluchit-nazvanie-krestovskiy|title=Стадион получит название "Крестовский" - Официальный сайт стадиона Зенит-Арена / Питер-Арена на Крестовском острове|publisher=}} ({{lang-ru|стадион «Крестовский»}}), officially '''Saint Petersburg Stadium''', also called '''Zenit Arena''', is a retractable roof [[stadium]] in the western portion of [[Krestovsky Island]] in [[Saint Petersburg]], Russia, which serves as home for [[FC Zenit Saint Petersburg]]{{ru icon}} [http://www.gorzakaz.org/news.php?id=3848 St. Petersburg Gorzakaz construction tender announcement]. The stadium was opened in 2017 for the [[2017 FIFA Confederations Cup|FIFA Confederations Cup]].{{cite web|url=http://resources.fifa.com/mm/document/tournament/competition/02/89/57/39/eng_01_0617_rus-nzl_fulltime.pdf|title=Match report – Group A – Russia - New Zealand |publisher=}} Initially, it was planned to be completed by December 2008,[http://www.fc-zenit.ru/info/page.phtml?id=340 New stadium] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070819035541/http://www.fc-zenit.ru/info/page.phtml?id=340 |date=19 August 2007 }} at Zenit's website {{ru icon}} which was changed to late 2011 and changed again numerous times{{cite web|url=http://nvspb.ru/tops/gazprom-arena-luchshe-no-pozje-42431|title="Газпром-Арена". Лучше, но позже - Невское время|publisher=}} until it was scheduled to open in 2017. As of May 2017, the stadium was 518% late and 548% over budget.{{cite news|title=Case Study – What Happens When Corruption Meets Incompetence - Krestovsky Stadium|url=http://www.thinktankconsulting.ca/what-happens-when-corruption-meets-incompetence-krestovsky-stadium|accessdate=3 June 2017|publisher=Moscow Times|date=13 May 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://tass.com/sport/922438 |title=FIFA confident that stadium in St. Petersburg will meet all requirements |publisher=TASS |date=26 December 2016 |accessdate=30 December 2016}} The stadium has a capacity of 67,000 people.{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/destination/stadiums/stadium=5031303/index.html|title=2018 FIFA World Cup Russia - Destination - FIFA.com|first=|last=FIFA.com|publisher=}} It was called '''Saint Petersburg Stadium''' during the [[2017 FIFA Confederations Cup]]{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/confederationscup/destination/cities/city=1771/index.html|title=FIFA Confederations Cup Russia 2017 - Saint Petersburg - FIFA.com|first=|last=FIFA.com|publisher=}} and [[2018 FIFA World Cup]].[https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/news/y=2015/m=10/news=stadium-names-for-the-2018-fifa-world-cup-russiatm-confirmed-2709881.html Stadium names for the 2018 FIFA World Cup Russia™ confirmed]. [[FIFA]]. At a cost of $1.1 billion at current exchange rates, it is considered one of the most expensive stadiums ever built. [https://5hotnews.com/2017/01/27/elusive-arena-krestovsky-and-4-most-expensive-football-stadium Elusive arena. “Krestovsky” and 4 “most expensive” football stadium] 27.01.2017 ==Overview== The competition between architectural projects was won by [[Kisho Kurokawa]]'s "The Spaceship". The design of the stadium is a modified and enlarged version of [[Toyota Stadium]] in [[Toyota, Aichi|Toyota City]], Japan, which was also designed by Kurokawa. The stadium was built on the location where the former [[Kirov Stadium]] used to stand before it was demolished. In January 2009 ''[[The St. Petersburg Times]]'' reported that the project was now to be funded by the city government of St Petersburg, with Gazprom switching to build a separate skyscraper project. The City Hall had to step in after [[Gazprom]] declined to invest any further money into the stadium's construction.{{cite web|url=http://www.times.spb.ru/index.php?action_id=2&story_id=27986 |title=City Hall Pulls Out of Skyscraper, Redirects Funds to New Stadium|publisher=The St. Petersburg Times |date=13 January 2009 |accessdate=27 May 2012}} On 25 July 2016 the general contractor, Inzhtransstroy-Spb, issued a statement that the city authorities have failed to pay 1 billion rubles ($15.8 million at the current exchange rate) worth of construction work and stopped the work. The next day the contract was terminated. On 1 August there were reports of wind damage to parts of the metal sheathing, and a flood.{{Cite web|url=https://lenta.ru/news/2016/08/01/zenit/|title=У "Зенит-Арены" снесло крышу|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|language=Russian|access-date=9 August 2016}}{{Cite web|url=https://lenta.ru/news/2016/08/02/zinith/|title=Строящийся стадион "Зенита" начал уходить под воду|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|language=Russian|access-date=9 August 2016}} In the end of August 2016, the new general contractor, Metrostroy, resumed construction works on the site.{{Cite web|url=https://www.championat.com/football/_worldcup/news-2568966-mutko-uroven-bespokojstva-za-stadion-v-sankt-peterburge-ponizjat-v-sentjabre.html|title= Мутко: уровень беспокойства за стадион в Санкт-Петербурге понизят в сентябре|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|language=Russian|access-date=4 September 2016}} The first official match held at the stadium was the [[Russian Premier League]] game between [[FC Zenit Saint Petersburg]] and [[FC Ural]] on 22 April 2017. [[Branislav Ivanović]] scored the first goal in the stadium's history. On 17 June 2017, the first game of [[2017 FIFA Confederations Cup]] was held on the stadium with the [[2017 FIFA Confederations Cup Group A|Group A]] match between the host [[Russia national football team|Russia]] and [[New Zealand national football team|New Zealand]]. On 2 July 2017, the [[2017 FIFA Confederations Cup Final|2017 FIFA Confederations Cup final match]] was held at the stadium between [[Chile national football team|Chile]] and [[Germany national football team|Germany]],{{cite web|url=http://resources.fifa.com/mm/document/tournament/competition/02/90/00/83/eng_16_0702_chi-ger_fulltime.pdf|title=Match report – Final – Chile - Germany|publisher=}} becoming the most attended match of the tournament and also setting the record attendance for the stadium. {{Panorama |image = File:Fina-l2017.jpg |height = 351 |width = 1158 |alt = |caption =
A photograph of the stadium
during [[2017 FIFA Confederations Cup Final|2017 FIFA Confederations Cup final match]] }} {{Panorama |image = File:2017 Confederations Cup - Final.jpg |height = 351 |width = 1158 |alt = |caption =
A [[panoramic]] photograph of the stadium
during [[2017 FIFA Confederations Cup Final|2017 FIFA Confederations Cup final match]] warm-up }} ==Gallery==

England |website=FIFA.com |publisher=[[FIFA|Fédération Internationale de Football Association]] |format=PDF |date=14 July 2018 |access-date=14 July 2018}} |} ==UEFA Euro 2020== On 19 September 2014, it was announced by UEFA that the stadium will host four [[Euro 2020]] finals fixtures, three group games and a quarterfinal match.{{cite web|url=https://www.uefa.com/uefaeuro-2020/#/|title=UEFA EURO 2020|first=|last=UEFA.com|website=UEFA.com}} {{clear}} {|class="wikitable" style="text-align:left; width:100%;" |- !Date !Time !Team #1 !Res. !Team #2 !Round !Attendance |- |13 June 2020|| || B3 ||style="text-align:center;"| – || B4 ||[[2020 UEFA Euro Group B|Group B]]||style="text-align:center;"| |- |17 June 2020|| || B1 ||style="text-align:center;"| – || B3 ||[[2020 UEFA Euro Group B|Group B]]||style="text-align:center;"| |- |22 June 2020|| || B2 ||style="text-align:center;"| – || B3 ||[[2020 UEFA Euro Group B|Group B]]||style="text-align:center;"| |- |3 July 2020|| 19:00 || Winner Match 41 ||style="text-align:center;"| – || Winner Match 42 ||[[2020 UEFA Euro knockout stage#Quarter-finals|Quarter-finals]]||style="text-align:center;"| |} == Services == The following services are available to fans visiting the stadium: * Navigation and information support from volunteers. * Information (children registration point, stroller storage, lost and found office). * Storage room. * Audio descriptive commentary for fans who are blind or visually impaired. Seating options include non-standard seats for plus-size spectators. The stadium stands include special observation area for people with disabilities, which offers space for wheelchairs and accompanying persons. === Conditions for Spectators with Disabilities === Saint Petersburg Arena offers 560 seats for people with disabilities, 266 of them are for wheelchair users.{{Cite news|url=https://sankt-peterburg.glavny.tv/news/52329|title=Люди с ограниченными возможностями протестировали стадион "Санкт-Петербург Арена"|date=2017-03-06|work=sankt-peterburg.glavny.tv|access-date=2018-06-14|language=ru}} Moreover, the stadium design includes special lobbies, elevators and ramps to ensure accessibility to spectators with limited mobility.{{Cite web|url=http://spb2018.com/ru/pages/arena/tech/#8|title=Технические характеристики {{!}} Чемпионат мира по футболу FIFA 2018 в России™ {{!}} Город-организатор Санкт-Петербург|website=spb2018.com|access-date=2018-06-14}} == Safety and security == The stadium has been fully prepared for the FIFA World Cup games in accordance with the FIFA requirements for capacity and security.{{Cite web|url=http://spb2018.com/ru/pages/arena/tech/|title=Технические характеристики {{!}} Чемпионат мира по футболу FIFA 2018 в России™ {{!}} Город-организатор Санкт-Петербург|website=spb2018.com|access-date=2018-06-14}} The stadium is equipped with a video surveillance and identification system that makes it possible to detect any troublemakers and fans who are not allowed to enter.{{Cite news|url=https://matchtv.ru/football/matchtvnews_NI821427_Direktor_po_bezopasnosti_Zenita_Starajemsa_chtoby_na_arene_Sankt_Peterburg_ludam_bylo_komfortno|title=Директор по безопасности «Зенита»: «Делаем все, чтобы на арене «Санкт-Петербург» людям было комфортно»|access-date=2018-06-14|language=ru-RU}} The arena is also equipped with a security alarm system, a fire alarm system and a robotic fire-extinguishing system. ==Picture gallery== New football stadium construction site in SPB 01.jpg|Construction as of August 2012 Zenit stadium (December 2014).jpg|Construction as of December 2014 RUS-2016-Aerial-SPB-Krestovsky Stadium 01.jpg|Construction as of July 2016 ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commonscat|Krestovsky Stadium}} * [http://piterarena.com/en Official website] {{Infobox company |name = Luanvi |logo = Luanvi.png |logo_size = 120px |type = [[Private company|Private]] |foundation = 1970s |location = [[Paterna]], [[Spain]] |key_people = |industry = [[Sportswear (activewear)|Sportswear]] |products = [[Association football|Football]], [[basketball]], [[Sports equipment|equipment]] and [[apparel]] |revenue = |homepage = [http://www.luanvi.es/ www.luanvi.es] }}
'''Luanvi''' is a Spanish [[Sportswear (activewear)|sportswear]] manufacturer, which currently produces [[Sports equipment|equipment]] and [[apparel]] for [[association football|football]], [[basketball]], [[handball]] and [[volleyball]]. Its headquarters are located in the city of [[Paterna]], [[Spain]].

Browning Day Mullins Dierdorf, Inc.{{cite web |title=Lucas Oil Stadium|url=http://www.bdmd.com/paplay/sports/arenas/lucas-oil-stadium-indianapolis-indiana-.html|publisher=Browning Day Mullins Dierdorf, Inc.|accessdate=February 6, 2014}} | project_manager = John Klipsch Consulting LLC{{cite web |title=Lucas Oil Stadium – Home of the Indianapolis Colts|url=http://johnklipschconsulting.com/blog/?page_id=109|publisher=John Klipsch Consulting LLC|accessdate=February 6, 2014}} | structural engineer = [[Walter P Moore Engineers and Consultants|Walter P Moore]]/Fink Roberts & Petrie{{cite web |title=Lucas Oil Stadium|url=http://www.emporis.com/application/?lng=3&nav=building&id=222480|publisher=Emporis|accessdate=January 10, 2012}} | services engineer = Moore Engineers PC{{cite web|url=http://www.archdaily.com/205212/super-bowl-xlvi-lucas-oil-stadium/|title=Super Bowl XLVI/Lucas Oil Stadium|publisher=ArchDaily|accessdate=October 19, 2012}}{{cite web|url=http://www.kibi.org/news/indianapolis_international_airport_receives_the_2009_monumental_award|title=Indianapolis International Airport Receives the 2009 Monumental Award|publisher=Kibi.org|date=November 19, 2009|accessdate=October 19, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100114030115/http://www.kibi.org/news/indianapolis_international_airport_receives_the_2009_monumental_award|archivedate=January 14, 2010|df=}} | general_contractor = Hunt/Smoot/Mezzetta | tenants = [[Indianapolis Colts]] ([[National Football League|NFL]]; 2008–present)
[[Indy Eleven]] ([[USL Championship|USLC]]; 2018–present) | suites = 139 | seating_capacity = [[American football]]: 67,000 (expandable to 70,000){{cite news |url=http://www.indystar.com/article/20120801/SPORTS03/120801034/Indianapolis-Colts-Team-will-turn-single-game-tickets-chase-sellouts|title=Indianapolis Colts: Team Will Turn to Single-Game Tickets in Chase for Sellouts|first=Mike|last=Chappel|newspaper=[[The Indianapolis Star]]|date=August 1, 2012|accessdate=September 6, 2012}}
[[Basketball]]: 70,000 (approx) }} '''Lucas Oil Stadium''' is a multi-purpose stadium in [[Downtown Indianapolis|Downtown]] [[Indianapolis]], [[Indiana]], [[United States]]. It replaced the [[RCA Dome]] as the home field of the [[National Football League|NFL]]'s [[Indianapolis Colts]] and opened on August 16, 2008.{{cite press release |title=Iscba Announces Lucas Oil Stadium Grand Opening Events|url=http://www.in.gov/iscba/files/LOS_Grand_Opening_events_release(1).doc|date=June 23, 2008|publisher=ISCBA|accessdate=January 10, 2012}} The stadium was constructed to allow the removal of the RCA Dome and expansion of the [[Indiana Convention Center]] on its site. The stadium is on the south side of South Street, a block south of the former site of the RCA Dome. In 2006, prior to the stadium's construction, [[Lucas Oil]] Products secured the naming rights for the stadium at a cost of $122 million over 20 years. {{cite news |title=Lucas Oil Gets Stadium Naming Rights, Colts Confirm|url=http://www.theindychannel.com/sports/7581942/detail.html|date=March 1, 2006|work=[[WRTV]]|publisher=wrtv.com|accessdate=January 10, 2012}} The venue also serves as the current home for the [[United Soccer League]]'s [[Indy Eleven]]. The architectural firm [[HKS, Inc.]] was responsible for the stadium's design, with [[Walter P Moore Engineers and Consultants|Walter P Moore]] working as the Structural Engineer of Record. The stadium features a retractable roof and window wall, thus allowing the Colts and the Eleven to play both indoors and outdoors. The field surface was originally [[FieldTurf]] but was replaced in 2018 with Shaw Sports Momentum Pro.{{cite web |url=https://www.shawsportsturf.com/projects/indianapolis-colts-lucas-oil-stadium-(1)/}} The exterior of the new stadium is faced with a reddish-brown [[brick]] trimmed with [[Indiana Limestone]], similar to several other sports venues in the area such as [[Bankers Life Fieldhouse]], [[Hinkle Fieldhouse]], and the [[Fairgrounds Coliseum]].{{cite news|title=If You Build It...|url=http://www2.indystar.com/users/factfiles/landmarks/0423_stadium_graphic.pdf|newspaper=[[The Indianapolis Star]]|accessdate=January 10, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111114113241/http://www2.indystar.com/users/factfiles/landmarks/0423_stadium_graphic.pdf|archivedate=November 14, 2011|df=}} ==Features== [[File:LucasOilStadiumTheLuke.jpg|left|thumb|Interior of Lucas Oil Stadium]] Lucas Oil Stadium has a seating capacity of 67,000 {{cite web |title=Facts and Information|url=http://www.lucasoilstadium.com/about.aspx|publisher=Lucas Oil Stadium|year=2008|accessdate=January 10, 2012}} and covers approximately 1.8 million square feet. The stadium offers 139 suites, two club lounges, two exhibit halls and 12 meeting rooms. There are also 360 degree ribbon boards and two massive high definition video boards. {{cite news|last=Ingerson |first=Meagan |title=Lucas Oil Stadium Scoreboards: 53 feet high, $11.4M Pricetag |publisher=indystar.com |date=November 26, 2007 |newspaper=[[The Indianapolis Star]] |url=http://www.indystar.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20071126/SPORTS/71126042 |accessdate=November 26, 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071128150526/http://www.indystar.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20071126%2FSPORTS%2F71126042 |archivedate=November 28, 2007 |deadurl=yes |df= }} An underground walkway directly connects the stadium to the Indiana Convention Center. Other features include: * 183,000 square feet of exhibit space * 7 locker rooms * 11 indoor truck docks * 14 escalators * 11 passenger elevators * 2 accessible pedestrian ramps ===Retractable Roof=== The stadium's retractable roof can open or close in 9 to 11 minutes. It is composed of two panels that each weigh 2.5 million pounds. {{cite web|title=Lucas Oil Stadium|url=http://www.uni-systems.com/en/projects/featured-projects/lucas-oil-stadium|publisher=Uni-Systems|accessdate=January 10, 2012}} ====NFL rules for roof opening==== The home team determines if the roof is to be opened or closed 90 minutes before kickoff. The roof remains open unless [[precipitation (meteorology)|precipitation]] or [[lightning]] is within the vicinity of the stadium, the [[temperature]] drops below {{convert|40|F}}, or [[wind speed|wind gusts]] are greater than {{convert|40|mph}}, in which case the roof operators will close the roof. Once the roof is closed, it is not allowed to be reopened. ===Retractable Window=== [[File:Lucas Oil Stadium - opening.JPG|thumb|Visitors can view the Indianapolis skyline through the northeast retractable window.]] The retractable north window offers a view of downtown Indianapolis during games, concerts and other events due to the stadium's angled position on the city block. {{cite web |title=Super Bowl XLV Visitor Guide: Stadium|url=http://www.nfl.com/superbowl/45/guide/stadium|publisher=NFL|accessdate=January 10, 2012}} ===Gate sponsorship=== The four gates leading into Lucas Oil Stadium are each named for sponsoring corporation: Lucas Oil, Verizon, HHGregg, and Huntington Bank. The ground-level concourses of their respective gates feature banners and floor coverings with the corporations' logos, advertisements and merchandise displays.{{cite news |title=HHGregg Signs On As Lucas Oil Stadium Founding Sponsor|url=http://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Daily/Issues/2007/12/Issue-63/Facilities-Venues/Hhgregg-Signs-On-As-Lucas-Oil-Stadium-Founding-Sponsor.aspx|work=SportsBusiness Daily|publisher=sportsbusinessdaily.com|date=December 11, 2007|accessdate=January 10, 2012}} {{clear}} ==Events== [[File:The final celebration (6837616839).jpg|thumb|[[Super Bowl XLVI]] post-game celebrations in 2012.]] [[File:04062015 Duke Wisconsin Pregame.jpg|thumb|Lucas Oil Stadium configured to host the 2015 [[NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship|NCAA Men's Basketball Final Four]].]] Annual events include: *[[Bands of America|Bands of America Grand National Championships and Indianapolis Super Regionals]] *[[Big Ten Football Championship Game]] {{cite news |date=December 3, 2011|url=http://espn.go.com/ncf/recap?gameId=313370127|publisher=[[ESPN]]|title=Montee Ball's Four Touchdowns Spark Wisconsin to Big Ten Title|agency=Associated Press|accessdate=January 10, 2012}} *[[Circle City Classic]] *[[Drum Corps International|Drum Corps International World Championships]] *[[FDIC International]] (Firefighting Convention) *[[Indiana High School Athletic Association|IHSAA Indiana State Football Championships]] *[[Indiana State School Music Association|ISSMA Band State Finals]] *[[AMA Supercross Championship|Monster Energy Supercross]] *[[Monster Jam]] *[[NFL scouting combine|NFL Draft Combine]] Upcoming events include: *[[General Conference Session]] of [[Seventh-day Adventists]] (June 25-July 4, 2020) *[[College Football Playoff National Championship]] (January 10, 2022) *[[NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship|NCAA Men's Basketball Final Four]] (April 2021) *[[NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship|NCAA Men's Basketball Final Four]] (April 2026) Significant past events included: *[[Super Bowl XLVI]] (February 5, 2012){{cite web|last=Callahan |first=Rick |url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/indianapolis-bid-2018-super-bowl-171211615.html|title=Indianapolis to make bid for 2018 Super Bowl|publisher=[[Yahoo! Finance]]|date=July 19, 2012|accessdate=October 19, 2012}} *Kenny Chesney (2008, 2009, 2012, 2015) *Chelsea vs. Inter Milan (International Champions Cup) (August 1, 2013) *[[NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship|NCAA Men's Basketball Final Four]] (2010, 2015) *[[One Direction]] – [[On The Road Again Tour]] (July 31, 2015) *[[Gen Con]] 50 (August 2017) *[[U2]] – [[The Joshua Tree Tour 2017]] (September 10, 2017) *[[Reputation Tour|Taylor Swift's Reputation Stadium Tour]] (September 15, 2018){{Cite journal|date=2017-12-13|title=Taylor Swift's Reputation Stadium Tour|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Taylor_Swift%27s_Reputation_Stadium_Tour&oldid=815249566|journal=Wikipedia|language=en}} ===Football=== The first games played at Lucas Oil Stadium occurred on August 22, 2008 and were part of the PeyBack Classic, featuring Indiana High School Football games between [[Noblesville High School]] and [[Fishers High School]] in Game 1, followed by [[New Palestine High School]] and [[Whiteland Community High School]] in Game 2.{{cite press release |title=Lucas Oil Stadium Preparing For Grand Opening Events|url=http://www.insideindianabusiness.com/newsitem.asp?ID=30892|publisher=Inside Indiana Business|work=Indiana Stadium and Convention Building Authority|date=June 24, 2008|accessdate=January 10, 2012}} On November 26, 2008, [[Cardinal Ritter High School]] became the first high school to win a state championship on the field, beating [[Sheridan High School (Indiana)|Sheridan High School]] 34-27 for the class A state title. The Colts faced the [[Chicago Bears]] in a rematch of [[Super Bowl XLI]]{{cite news |title=Colts Season Opener Puts New Stadium in National Spotlight|url=http://www.wthr.com/Global/story.asp?S=8094973&nav=menu188_2|work=[[WTHR]]|publisher=wthr.com|first=Mary|last=Milz|date=March 31, 2008|accessdate=January 10, 2012}} in their first regular season game in the stadium. ===Soccer=== The stadium hosted its first soccer game on August 1, 2013, when [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] played [[Internazionale|Inter Milan]] in a first-round game of the [[International Champions Cup]], drawing 41,983 fans.{{cite web|title=Guinness International Champion Cup Teams, Venues, and Bracket Announced|url=http://internationalchampionscup.com/news/article/guinness-international-champions-cup-teams-venues-and-bracket-announced/|publisher=http://internationalchampionscup.com/|accessdate=June 28, 2013}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left; width:95%;" style="text-align:center" |- !style="text-align:center; {{NFLPrimaryStyle|Indianapolis Colts}};"|Date !style="text-align:center; {{NFLPrimaryStyle|Indianapolis Colts}};"|Winning Team !style="text-align:center; {{NFLPrimaryStyle|Indianapolis Colts}};"|Result !style="text-align:center; {{NFLPrimaryStyle|Indianapolis Colts}};"|Losing Team !style="text-align:center; {{NFLPrimaryStyle|Indianapolis Colts}};"|Tournament !style="text-align:center; {{NFLPrimaryStyle|Indianapolis Colts}};"|Spectators |- |style="text-align:center;|August 1, 2013||'''{{flagicon|ENG}} [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]]'''||style="text-align:center;|2–0|| {{flagicon|ITA}} [[Internazionale|Inter Milan]] ||style="text-align:center;|[[2013 International Champions Cup]] First Round||style="text-align:center;|41,983 |} As of 2018, Lucas Oil Stadium serves as the home field for the [[United Soccer League]]'s [[Indy Eleven]], replacing the venue they used while in the [[North American Soccer League]], [[IU Michael A. Carroll Track & Soccer Stadium|Carroll Stadium]].{{cite news|last=Mack|first=Justin|title='We can't wait to see you at our new venue.' Indy Eleven headed to Lucas Oil Stadium|url=https://www.indystar.com/story/sports/2018/01/29/indy-eleven-play-lucas-oil-stadium-2018-after-move-usl/1074045001/|date=January 29, 2018}} ===Entertainment=== [[Drum Corps International]] (DCI) announced on August 9, 2006 that it would move its corporate offices to Indianapolis and that the DCI World Championships would be the inaugural event for the stadium and would be held at Lucas Oil Stadium every year through 2018.{{cite press release |title=Drum Corps International Moving Headquarters, Bringing World Championships to Indianapolis|url=http://www.dci.org/news/view.cfm?news_id=ed104f9d-2d1f-4f59-9c9f-c64d6c7b9bbe|date=August 9, 2006|publisher=Drum Corps International|accessdate=January 10, 2012}} In 2015, Drum Corps International and the city of Indianapolis announced a 10-year contract extension, allowing the World Championships to continue through 2028.http://www.dci.org/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_LANG=C&DB_OEM_ID=33500&ATCLID=210253294&SPID=166025&SPSID=965782 The competition was held for the first time at Lucas Oil Stadium in 2009.{{cite press release |title=2008 Drum Corps International World Championships Relocated to Indiana University|publisher=DCI|date=April 4, 2008|url=http://www.dci.org/news/view.cfm?news_id=1ff99128-7572-4268-a029-abcd6f085998|accessdate=January 10, 2012}} Other regular events include the [[Bands of America]] Grand National Championships{{cite press release |title=2011 Grand National Championships Review|url=http://www.musicforall.org/what-we-do/marching/grand-national-championships/2011-grand-national-championships-review| date=12 November 2011|publisher=Music For All|accessdate=January 10, 2012}} and the [[Indiana Marching Band State Finals]],{{cite news |title=Bands Take the Field at Lucas Oil Stadium for Annual Competition|url=http://www.courierpress.com/news/2011/oct/30/48pt-hed1-15-inches-of-story/|newspaper=[[Evansville Courier & Press]]|first=Eric|last=Bradner|publisher=courierpress.com|accessdate=January 10, 2012}} both major events for the city in [[Marching band]] competitions. ====Concerts==== {| class="wikitable" style=font-size:100% style="text-align:center" |- ! width=12% style="text-align:center;{{NFLPrimaryStyle|Indianapolis Colts}};|Date ! width=10% style="text-align:center;{{NFLPrimaryStyle|Indianapolis Colts}};|Artist ! width=10% style="text-align:center;{{NFLPrimaryStyle|Indianapolis Colts}};|Opening Act(s) ! width=16% style="text-align:center;{{NFLPrimaryStyle|Indianapolis Colts}};|Tour / Concert Name ! width=10% style="text-align:center;{{NFLPrimaryStyle|Indianapolis Colts}};|Attendance ! width=10% style="text-align:center;{{NFLPrimaryStyle|Indianapolis Colts}};|Revenue ! width=10% style="text-align:center;{{NFLPrimaryStyle|Indianapolis Colts}};|Notes |- | September 13, 2008 || [[Kenny Chesney]] || [[Keith Urban]]
[[LeAnn Rimes]]
[[Gary Allan]]
[[Luke Bryan]]
[[Sammy Hagar]] || The Poets and Pirates Tour || 50,528 / 50,528 || $3,835,609 || The stadium's first public concert.{{cite news |title=Chesney Concert Will Be First at Lucas Oil Stadium|url=http://www.wthr.com/Global/story.asp?S=8999255|publisher=wthr.com|work=WTHR|date=September 16, 2008|accessdate=January 10, 2012}} |- | September 19, 2009 || [[Kenny Chesney]] || [[Miranda Lambert]]
[[Sugarland]]

[[Chase Rice]]
[[Old Dominion (band)|Old Dominion]] || [[The Big Revival Tour]] || 43,675 / 44,872 || $4,064,335 || |- | July 31, 2015 || [[One Direction]] || [[Icona Pop]] || [[On the Road Again Tour]] || 42,196 / 42,196 || $3,426,589 || |- | September 10, 2017 || [[U2]] || [[Beck]] || [[The Joshua Tree Tour 2017]] || 51,731 / 51,731 || $5,970,055 || |- | September 15, 2018 || [[Taylor Swift]] || [[Camila Cabello]]
[[Charli XCX]] || [[Taylor Swift's Reputation Stadium Tour]] || 55,729 / 55,729 || $6,531,245 || Highest attended concert at the stadium.{{cite news |title=4 ways Taylor Swift aced her stadium challenge in Indianapolis|url=https://www.indystar.com/story/entertainment/music/2018/09/16/4-ways-taylor-swift-aced-her-stadium-challenge-indianapolis/1253766002/|publisher=indystar.com|work=IndyStar|date=September 16, 2018|accessdate=September 17, 2018}} |} ==Financing== The total cost of Lucas Oil Stadium was $720 million. The stadium is being financed with funds raised by the State of Indiana and the City of Indianapolis, with the Indianapolis Colts providing $100 million. [[Marion County, Indiana|Marion County]] has raised taxes for food and beverage sales, auto rental taxes, innkeeper's taxes, and admission taxes for its share of the costs. Meanwhile, there has been an increase in food and beverage taxes in the 8 surrounding [[Indianapolis metropolitan area|doughnut counties]] (with the exception of [[Morgan County, Indiana|Morgan County]]) and the sale of Colts license plates. The County Commissioners of each county voted whether to levy the 1% food and beverage tax proposed by Marion County. Sweetening the deal for those counties was the fact that half of the revenue from the tax would stay in the respective county. [[Morgan County, Indiana|Morgan County]] was the only county to turn down the offer, yet in a later vote, it levied its own 1% tax – thus keeping ''all'' of its additional generated revenue. ===Budget shortfall=== In August 2006, the Capital Improvement Board, which operates the stadium, estimated that daily operating expenses of the new stadium would be $10 million more per year than the RCA Dome. The board urged the [[Indiana General Assembly]] to authorize funding to cover the shortfall.{{cite news |title=Operating in the Red Zone: Stadium Plan Faces Shortfall on Day-to-Day Costs|first=Karen|last=Eschbacher|newspaper=[[The Indianapolis Star]]|date=August 27, 2006|publisher=Pacer Digest|url=http://www.pacersdigest.com/apache2-default/showthread.php?t=23624|accessdate=January 10, 2012}} The Indiana Legislature considered a bill to raise sales taxes statewide to cover the shortfall, however this plan faces stiff opposition from legislators outside the Indianapolis metro area.{{cite news |title=CIB President: Stadium Could Close If Deal Isn't Reached|url=http://www.theindychannel.com/money/19090648/detail.html|date=April 3, 2009|publisher=WRTV|accessdate=January 10, 2012}} The assembly ultimately authorized a tax increase in Indianapolis-Marion County. In addition, the CIB trimmed staff and cut $10 million from its budget. Still, the agency anticipated a $20 million operating deficit for Lucas Oil Stadium in 2009. Anticipated expenses are $27.7 million—far outstripping the $7.7 million CIB expects to collect from its share of revenue from stadium events.{{cite news |title=More Layoffs, Furloughs Possible for Cash-Strapped Indianapolis CIB|url=http://www.indianaeconomicdigest.net/main.asp?SectionID=31&SubSectionID=62&ArticleID=49947|first=Scott|last=Olson|work=Indianapolis Business Journal|date=September 15, 2009|publisher=Indiana Economic Digest|accessdate=January 10, 2012}} The Colts organization has been criticized for the favorable lease terms and the high percentage of revenue it can keep under the terms of its agreements with the stadium authorities and there have been calls for the team to cover the shortfalls of the CIB. The Colts responded to these criticisms in an open letter to fans on September 16, 2009.{{cite news |title=Colts Letter to Fans on Lucas Oil Stadium|url=http://www.wthr.com/story/10239297/colts-letter-to-fans-on-lucas-oil-stadium?redirected=true|date=September 16, 2009|publisher=wthr.com|work=WTHR|accessdate=January 10, 2012}} ==Complications== On September 8, 2013 after the Colts defeated the Oakland Raiders in the season opener, a rail over the opposing team tunnel collapsed injuring two fans. One fan was transferred to the hospital for evaluation. No serious injuries were reported. On September 3, 2015, three fans were injured by a bolt that fell from the roof of the stadium as it was being opened during an NFL preseason game against the Cincinnati Bengals.{{cite news |title=Three fans injured during Colts game after bolt falls from Lucas Oil Stadium roof|first=Matt|last=Bonesteel|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|date=September 4, 2015|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/early-lead/wp/2015/09/04/three-fans-injured-during-colts-game-after-bolt-falls-from-lucas-oil-stadium-roof|accessdate=September 19, 2015}} The stadium was pronounced safe by officials, but the roof was to remain closed for events until a final investigation was completed as to why the bolt fell.{{cite news |title=Officials: Lucas Oil Stadium safe for events with roof closed, bolt investigation continues|url=http://fox59.com/2015/09/18/officials-to-provide-update-on-bolt-that-fell-from-roof-of-lucas-oil-stadium|date=September 18, 2015|publisher=fox59.com|work=Fox 59|accessdate=September 19, 2015}} ==Construction pictures== File:Lucas Oil Stadium 080207.jpg|Early phases of construction File:LucasOilStadiumBuiltSat.png|Satellite image File:LucasOil earlystages.JPG|Mid-stage of construction ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{external links|date=January 2018}} {{Commons category|Lucas Oil Stadium}} *{{Official website}} *[http://football.ballparks.com/NFL/IndianapolisColts/newindex.htm Lucas Oil Stadium page at ''Ballparks.com''] *[http://wheresmyseat.net/lucas-oil-stadium/ Lucas Oil Stadium Seating Chart] *[http://www.in.gov/iscba/ Indiana Stadium and Convention Building Authority] *[http://www.emporis.com/en/wm/bu/?id=222480 Emporis Buildings Site Info] page.title: Musée de la Chasse et de la Nature

revision.text:
[[File:Musee de la Chasse et de la Nature signage.jpg|180px|right]] The '''Musée de la Chasse et de la Nature''' (Museum of Hunting and Nature) is a private museum of [[hunting]] and [[nature]] located in the [[3rd arrondissement of Paris]], [[France]]. The museum is served by the [[Rambuteau (Paris Métro)|Rambuteau]] [[Paris Métro]] station.
Exhibits focus on the relationships between humans and the natural environment through the traditions and practices of hunting.<ref>{{cite web|title=Musée de la Chasse et de la Nature|url=http://www.chassenature.org/site_musee/musee-collect.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070912204821/http://www.chassenature.org/site_musee/musee-collect.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=12 September 2007|work=Les Musée et ses Collections|accessdate=31 August 2011}}</ref> The museum has been characterized by the ''Smithsonian'' magazine as “one of the most rewarding and inventive in Paris",<ref>{{cite news|last=Perrottet|first=Tony|title=The Offbeat Museums of Europe|url=http://www.smithsonianmag.com/travel/The-Offbeat-Museums-of-Europe.html|accessdate=31 August 2011|newspaper=Smithsonian magazine|date=17 May 2011}}</ref> and is described in tourist guidebooks and other media as "quirky, astonishing, strange and eclectic".<ref>{{cite book|last=Cantu|first=Juan and Dorothy McLeod|title=Let's Go Paris: The Student Travel Guide|year=2010|publisher=Harvard Student Agencies|isbn=1-59880-709-9|pages=77|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xWea53iApFAC&pg=PA77&dq=Mus%C3%A9e+de+la+Chasse+et+de+la+Nature&hl=en&ei=zFheTrLoO6XXiAKGiumzBQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0CEkQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=Mus%C3%A9e%20de%20la%20Chasse%20et%20de%20la%20Nature&f=false}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Dorkin|first=Paige|title=Running with Deer and Hunting with Hounds|url=http://www.parismarais.com/le-marais-museum-guide.htm|accessdate=31 August 2011|newspaper=The Paris Times|date=February 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Eric Poitevin au Musée de la Chasse|url=http://www.photosapiens.com/Eric-Poitevin-au-musee-de-la-chasse.html|accessdate=31 August 2011|newspaper=Photosapiens SARL}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Musée de la Chasse et de la Nature: Stuffed with fantasy|url=http://paris.unlike.net/locations/304291-Mus-e-de-la-Chasse-et-de-la-Nature|accessdate=31 August 2011|newspaper=Paris Unlike}}</ref>
==Origins== [[File:Philippe le Beau M de la Chasse.jpg|thumb|180px|[[Philip the Handsome]] (1478-1506), [[Duke of Burgundy]], holding a hooded [[falcon]], displayed in the Falconry Room]] The museum was founded in 1964 by wealthy French industrialist rugmaker [[François Sommer]] (1904-1973) and his wife Jacqueline, who were avid hunters and conservationists. It is operated by the [[Fondation de la Maison de la Chasse et de la Nature]], which the couple also founded.<ref>{{cite web|title=FRANÇOIS ET JACQUELINE SOMMER|url=http://www.chassenature.org/site_musee/musee-collect/fondateurs.html|publisher=Fondation de la Maison de la Chasse and Nature|accessdate=31 August 2011}}</ref> The museum is housed within the [[Hôtel de Guénégaud]] (1651-1655), the only private mansion designed by architect [[François Mansart]] that still exists.<ref>{{cite book|last=Cantu|first=Juan and Dorothy McLeod|title=Let's Go Paris: The Student Travel Guide|year=2010|publisher=Harvard Student Agencies|isbn=1-59880-709-9|pages=77|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xWea53iApFAC&pg=PA77&dq=Mus%C3%A9e+de+la+Chasse+et+de+la+Nature&hl=en&ei=zFheTrLoO6XXiAKGiumzBQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0CEkQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=Mus%C3%A9e%20de%20la%20Chasse%20et%20de%20la%20Nature&f=false}}</ref> Since 2002, it is also housed in the [[Hôtel de Mongelas]] (1703), as well. It opened in 1967 and was thoroughly renovated in 2007.<ref>{{cite news|title=Musée de la Chasse: Hunting in Paris|url=http://madaboutparis.com/culture/hunting-in-paris.html|accessdate=31 August 2011|newspaper=Mad About Paris}}</ref>
==Overview== [[File:Le Souillot.jpg|thumb|180px|Le Souillot, the talking boar head displayed in the Trophy Room]] The museum, housed in the limestone Hôtel de Guénégaud under a 99-year lease, is made up of multiple rooms paneled in wood and outfitted with bronze decorative fixtures designed by Brazilian sculptor [[Saint Clair Cemin]], and made to look like vines, antlers and tree branches.<ref>{{cite web|title=Saint Clair Cemin at the Musée de la Chasse et de la Nature|url=http://www.saintclaircemin.com/lemuseedelachasse.html|publisher=Saint Clair Cemin|accessdate=31 August 2011}}</ref> The ceiling of one room has been covered in owl feathers in a work called ''The Night of Diana''<ref>{{cite web|title=The night of Diana|url=http://www.angelos.be/EN/works/23|publisher=Jan Fabre|accessdate=31 August 2011}}</ref> by contemporary Belgian artist Jan Fabre,<ref>{{cite web|last=Beyst|first=Stefan|title=More Masterpieces of Jan Fabre|url=http://d-sites.net/english/fabremore.htm|publisher=Stefan Beyst|accessdate=31 August 2011}}</ref> previously known for decorating the ceiling of the Royal Palace in Brussels with more than a million and a half beetle wing cases.<ref>{{cite web|last=Spooky|title=A Beautiful, Bug-Infested Ceiling|url=http://www.odditycentral.com/pics/a-beautiful-bug-infested-ceiling.html|publisher=Oddity Central|accessdate=31 August 2011}}</ref> The museum's rooms have names such as Room of the Boar, Salon of the Dogs and Cabinet of the Wolf.<ref>{{cite web|title=L'image de l'animal|url=http://www.chassenature.org/site_musee/art-animal.html|publisher=Fondation de la Maison de la Chasse and Nature|accessdate=31 August 2011}}</ref>
The museum's chief curator is [[Claude d'Anthenaise]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Saint Clair Cemin at the Musée de la Chasse et de la Nature|url=http://www.saintclaircemin.com/lemuseedelachasse.html|publisher=Saint Clair Cemin|accessdate=31 August 2011}}</ref>
The collection is partly made up of objects and works that were gathered personally by François and Jacqueline Sommer: their collection totalled nearly three thousand hunting-related objects, including nearly five hundred engravings.<ref>{{cite web|title=Le musée & ses collections|url=http://www.chassenature.org/site_musee/musee-collect/fondateurs.html|publisher=Fondation de la Maison de la Chasse and Nature|accessdate=31 August 2011}}</ref>
The museum displays ancient and contemporary works together: in the Salon of the Dogs, a collection of gold dog collars throughout the ages is displayed alongside 17th-century portraits of [[Louis XIV]]'s pets and a small white version of the Scottie dog sculpture [[Jeff Koons#Puppy 1992|''Puppy'']] by contemporary American ceramic artist [[Jeff Koons]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Getting Gamey in Paris|url=http://gridskipper.com/archives/entries/62489/62489.php|accessdate=31 August 2011|newspaper=Gridskipper|date=28 July 2009}}</ref> It also includes fantastical elements: an alcove dedicated to unicorns contains a small curio cabinet, the 2005 video ''Unicorn'' by French video artist [[Maïder Fortune]], work by contemporary artist [[Jean-Michel Othoniel]], and a 1957 sculpture by [[Janine Janet]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Le Musée de la Chasse et de la Nature - PARIS|url=http://www.deyrolle.fr/magazine/spip.php?article227|publisher=Deyrolle magazine|accessdate=31 August 2011}}</ref>
==Collection== [[File:Salle des Trophees, M. de la Chasse et de la Nature 2.jpg|thumb|250px|Salle des Trophées]] The museum is organized around three themes: weapons and other instruments of hunting such as guns and horns; hunting products such as trophies and taxidermied animals; and artistic representations of wildlife and hunting such as paintings, prints, sculptures, tapestries, ceramics and furniture.<ref>{{cite web|title=Le musée & ses collections|url=http://www.chassenature.org/site_musee/musee-collect.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070912204821/http://www.chassenature.org/site_musee/musee-collect.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=12 September 2007|publisher=Fondation de la Maison de la Chasse and Nature|accessdate=31 August 2011}}</ref>
* '''Weapons and hunting accessories''' The museum includes an array of weaponry from the 16th through to the 19th centuries, including spears, cross bows, hunting horns, [[powder flask]]s and guns. Guns include ones owned by [[Louis XIII]], [[Marie Thérèse of Austria|Marie-Thérèse]] of Austria, [[Napoleon]] Ier, and [[Napoleon III]].
* '''Hunting products''' The museum houses hundreds of trophies and taxidermied animals from Europe, Africa, Asia and America. These include a polar bear, lion, tiger, cheetah, fox, rhinoceros, bison, water buffalo and many birds. In the Room of Trophies, ''Le Souillot'', a wall-mounted animatronic albino boar head by contemporary French artist [[Nicolas Darrot]], speaks to museum visitors in French.<ref>{{cite news|last=Vence|title=Musée de la Chasse et de la Nature|url=http://blog.paris3e.fr/post/2010/10/17/Musee-de-la-Chasse-et-de-la-Nature|accessdate=1 September 2011|newspaper=Paris 3e, la création qu'on aime!|date=17 October 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Ravishingbeasts|title=Exhibit: Stylish Beasts|url=http://www.ravishingbeasts.com/events/2007/1/1/exhibitstylish-beasts.html|accessdate=1 September 2011|newspaper=Ravishing Beasts Taxidermy|date=1 January 2007}}</ref>
*'''Paintings and sculptures''' The museum includes representations of hunting and nature scenes by historically significant artists such as Flemish Baroque painter [[Peter Paul Rubens]], German Renaissance painter [[Lucas Cranach the Elder]], 17th-century Flemish painter [[Frans Snyders]], official 'painter of the hunt and animals' [[Alexandre-François Desportes]] and naturalistic French Rococo painter [[Jean-Baptiste Oudry]], as well as contemporary artists such as Belgian multidisciplinary artist and sculptor [[Jan Fabre]], French glass sculptor [[Jean-Michel Othoniel]] and contemporary French watercolour painter [[Francoise Petrovitch]].
== See also == * [[List of museums in Paris]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Musée de la chasse et de la nature}} *[http://www.chassenature.org/#1 Official Site]
{{coord|48|51|40|N|2|21|31|E|type:landmark_region:FR|display=title}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Musee de la Chasse et de la Nature}} [[Category:Museums in Paris]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in the 3rd arrondissement of Paris]] [[Category:Hunting museums]] [[Category:Natural history museums in France]]

{{Infobox cricket tournament main | tournament name = National Cricket League | current = | image = | size = 150px | caption = | country = {{Flagicon|Bangladesh}} Bangladesh | administrator = [[Bangladesh Cricket Board]] | cricket format = [[List A cricket]] | first = 2000–01 | last = 2010–11 | tournament format = | participants = 8 | champions = | qualification = | most successful = | most runs = | most wickets = | website = }} The '''National Cricket League One-Day''' was the principal domestic [[limited overs cricket]] competition in [[Bangladesh]] from 2000–01 until 2010–11. It has since been superseded by the [[Dhaka Premier Division]] competition, which gained [[List A cricket|List A]] status in 2013.
==One-Day Cricket League Winners== * [[2000–01 Bangladeshi cricket season|2000–01]] – [[Biman Bangladesh Airlines cricket team|Biman Bangladeshi Airlines]] (1/1) * [[2001–02 Bangladeshi cricket season|2001–02]] – [[Sylhet Division cricket team|Sylhet Division]] (1/1) * [[2002–03 Bangladeshi cricket season|2002–03]] – [[Khulna Division cricket team|Khulna Division]] (1/1) * [[2003–04 Bangladeshi cricket season|2003–04]] – [[Chittagong Division cricket team|Chittagong Division]] (1/1) * [[2004–05 Bangladeshi cricket season|2004–05]] – [[Rajshahi Division cricket team|Rajshahi Division]] (1/3) * [[2005–06 Bangladeshi cricket season|2005–06]] – [[Rajshahi Division cricket team|Rajshahi Division]] (2/2) * [[2006–07 Bangladeshi cricket season|2006–07]] – [[Dhaka Division cricket team|Dhaka Division]] (1/2) * [[2007–08 Bangladeshi cricket season|2007–08]] – [[Rajshahi Division cricket team|Rajshahi Division]] (3/3) * [[2008–09 Bangladeshi cricket season|2008–09]] – [[Barisal Division cricket team|Barisal Division]] (1/1) * [[2010–11 Bangladeshi cricket season|2010–11]] – [[Dhaka Division cricket team|Dhaka Division]] (2/2)
